reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Protect fragile livelihoods of farmers affected by the Great March of Return in the access restricted area (ARA) through urgent livelihood support to restore their agricultural production capacity

description.narrative:
The financial crisis, which hit the Palestinian National Authority in March/April 2017, resulted in the cuts of salaries of public employees in the Gaza Strip (GS), delays in the payment of subsidies provided through the ministry of social development (MoSD), significant decrease in the medical referrals out of Gaza, and further negative consequences. In addition, the financial crisis within UNRWA, WFP, and all USAID funded INGOs greatly impacts the living conditions of Gazans.
Since March 30, 2018, mass demonstrations have been taking place every Friday along the fence with Israel, in the Access Restricted Area (ARA), which were severely repressed by the use of live ammunition. According to the latest figures from the Palestinian Ministry of Health (MoH), from 30th March till the end of September, 193 Palestinians have been killed and 21,150 injured during the demonstrations In addition, the presence of a high number of people and the use of tear gas and other means of retaliation by Israeli forces have heavily damaged agricultural fields and crops in the Access Restricted Area. More than 200 farmers who have their lands located within 500 meters from the fence were affected by the Great March of Return (GMR) and lost their crops.
The planned action aims to enhance affected farmers' capacity to cope with the current deteriorated situation through providing agricultural assistance to enable them resuming their agricultural activities and providing for their families. PUI plans to assist the affected farmers through the provision of unconditional/restricted cash assistance to help them restoring their production capacity and access their livelihoods, in order to avoid missing the spring planting season in coming February. Additionally, affected farmers who still have access to their lands or have alternative lands to cultivate will be supported with unconditional/restricted cash assistance to avoid missing the winter planting season which should start in November/December 2018.
The planned action was closely coordinated with the ICRC Food security sector and the MoA, as well as with the Union of Agricultural Work Committees (UAWC).
The different activities were discussed with the MoA and the FSS in order to provide the most effective and efficient intervention: provision of cash assistance.. All agreed that this intervention should complement ICRC’s intervention notably considering that the GMR is still ongoing.
To continue to work as effectively as possible, PUI will implement this action in close collaboration with the Union of Agricultural Work Committees (UAWC).

participating-org.narrative: Union of Agricultural Work Committees Local NGO (UAWC)

receiver-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
